awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigating Process-Structure-Property Correlations of Nitrides and Oxides for High Temperature Thermoelectric Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant provides funding to investigate new processing mechanisms of nanostructuring bulk nitrides and oxides with multiple length-scale structures for high temperature thermoelectric power generation. The underlying hypothesis is that multiple length-scale nanostructures can be controlled by process engineering and thus be used as an effective method to tune thermoelectric properties by decoupling electrical and thermal properties. To test this hypothesis, an integrated experimental and theoretical study is used to examine the processing-related parameters including atomic-scale, nanoscale, and micro-scale structures and their corresponding effects on thermoelectric properties. Gallium nitride and zinc oxide are the model systems for this work due to their promising thermoelectric properties and mechanical and chemical stability at high temperatures. 

If successful, this program will enable a new class of cost-effective, thermally stable and nontoxic thermoelectric materials for wasted energy recovery at high temperatures. A total of 1500 trillion BTU/year of waste heat is generated from industrial processes where temperatures typically exceed 1000K. A new class of thermoelectric materials that are robust up to 1000K will make a key contribution to recover this wasted energy since the operational temperature of current technology is limited to below 800K. The science gained from this project can be transformed more broadly into the further development of thermoelectric, photovoltaic, and laser devices. The educational contributions of this CAREER project include creating interdisciplinary education and research modules within energy-related curriculums, enhancing underrepresented students' participation in science and engineering, and outreach to K-12 students to pursue a career in science and engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF CAREER project is built upon the discovery and engineering of nanostructured oxides and nitrides thermoelectric (TE) materials for high temperature power generation. The research team discovered a new class of cost-effective, thermally stable, and non-toxic TE materials for wasted energy recovery at high temperature. A total of 1500 trillion BTU/year of waste heat is generated from industrial processes at high temperature. A new class of thermoelectric materials discovered from this study has a great potential to recover this wasted energy since they remain high TE efficiency at high temperature.

The team discovered several effective strategies to enhance TE performance of oxides and nitrides through electron-phonon decoupling, effective scattering mechanisms, and optimized doping concentration. The PI’s group has also advanced the knowledge base in nanostructure synthesis using metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD), solid states synthesis, and the electron-spinning process. Moreover, the research team developed a set of machine-learning based tools to perform material exploration of nano-structured oxides and nitrides for high temperature TE power generation. Such an approach has greatly reduced the experimental cost and improved the efficiency of materials discovery for high temperature TE materials.

The scientific contributions of this program included 1) filled knowledge gap on processing-structural-property relationship of oxides and nitrides for high temperature TE materials through integrated computational and experimental study; 2) developed a reliable and accurate materials encoding system that is suitable for AI-assisted material discovery model; 3) developed TE materials properties prediction model by using an AI algorithm. This program has identified several oxides and nitrides nanomaterials that are suitable for high temperature TE applications and their optimized doping concentrations. Also, the science gained from this study can be applied more broadly in other engineering applications, such as solar cells, laser diodes, plasmonic and other optoelectronic applications.

This CAREER program supported three postdoctoral scientists’ work, three PhD thesis study, and numerous master and undergraduate students’ research. The research results and knowledge base have been disseminated to scientific communities through 40 peer-reviewed publications, and numerous invited talks at national and international conferences. The new courses developed from this program have reached thousands of students worldwide through edX and Purdue Global, the largest online learning platform. This CAREER project has also made significant contributions to science and technology education through developing new curriculum integrating science and engineering, enhancing underrepresented students' participation, and outreach to K-12 students to pursue a career in science and engineering.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Na (Luna) Lu
